1.content:
Phineas Fortescue was an unremarkable lad. Even heading into his penultimate year of magic studies at the famed Citadel Prepatory Academy for Rites and Sorcery, he didn’t stand out next to his fellow young mages. There were teen wizards that knew more spells, budding warlocks with more prestige, co-ed witches that would not regard him for too long. Phineas was a remarkably bright student, yet outshadowed by the most eminent magical geniuses of the age and his introspective tendencies.

Seventeen year old Phineas spent just too much time in his head. It came from being the middle child in a vast family of magicians to pour out of the famed school with illustrious careers. Big things had been expected of Phineas, attention he found stifling just as he was coming into his own at the school.

Phineas loved puzzling out riddles. He had an analytic mind, obscure tastes, and tended to do well in the face of magical mysteries. He wasn’t good with natural magic in practice, by the book he was a swell student. He was clumsy around horticulture and supernatural creatures. He coasted through academy life at the Citadel not having many plans for the future, true passions or potential of any measurable kind compared to his peers.

Even his looks were kind of awkward. Bowl haircuts, dark hair and eyes, little in the realm of muscle on his lean frame. He was a fastidious dresser but kept to a stringent uniform of tie and robes, lacking any style beyond that of a bookish nerd. Even his family’s inclination towards a tall stock skipped Phineas’ conception, as he was of average height and build.

Phineas didn’t have many friends, acquaintances rather. His awkwardness extended to socializing as well, he constantly scrutinized each word he said in hopes of sounding different than he felt. Trying to sound clever or cool or tough when he was, in all honesty, kind of pathetic.

Phineas would continue drifting through life as a face in the crowd, an unremarkable wizard, be forever marked as average were it not for one of his deepest secrets:

He loved fat women.

Phineas couldn’t be sure just where his attraction had started. Roughly around the time he heard boys his age really talk about the kinds of girls they liked (or occasionally the other boys they liked, although that wasn’t where Phineas’ orientation lay) the young mage found that his ideals of beauty didn’t mesh with the common consensus. Skinny, high arched features, a tight petite feminine form. Phineas’s private fantasize drew to the curvy, the thick, the chubby, the chunky, the weighty, the huge, the obese, the massive…

Yeah, the larger the girl, the more Phineas started to get carried away. Citadel Prepatory Academy for Rites and Sorcery had its fair share of ample females. Magic carried with it an air of elitism and hubris, with some taking it too far with indulgences. Even if the feelings were mutual, Phineas feared he would never be able to express his desires towards the plus sized opposite sex without facing ridicule and disgust.

So Phineas kept his love of the large and fat secret into the start of his penultimate year at Citadel Prepatory Academy for Rites & Sorcery. Up until the moment he arrived at school.

Consider it a change of destiny or happening of circumstance. Phineas was about to see his wildest hopes met in ways he never considered possible. Phineas was about to find the love of his life.

Pity they were all vying for his attention, what with all of these weighty females coming out of the proverbial woodwork.

So where do we find Phineas Fortescue just as he finally catches a break with the large ladies?

11.content:
The Citadel Prepatory Academy for Rites & Sorcery prided itself on its extensive magical education. A slew of courses covered every conceivable topic at the fortress, from uncovering the ancient secrets of magic, improving the known body of spells and potions, and delving into the ecosystems of pure fantasy. Courses were challenging and prone to the mishaps to grace a school as young witches and wizards got a handle on their magic.

For Phineas Fortescue, it was a bittersweet time at the start of a new semester. On one hand, there were the thoughts of what might happen. What would be the newest topic to strike his curiosity? How would this class change his understanding of magic? And who would be in it, and would any of the girls have gained weight since last year...

Phineas felt himself get distracted. That was a tad optimistic. While he generally had decent first days in new classes, it wouldn't be long for his difficult subjects to rear their ugly heads. Try as he might, Phineas was not good with the practical side of natural magic, as it extended to magical plants and animals. His reflexes in dueling were sub-par. Overall Phineas was far better with theory and book learning, especially the dry sorts of classes like ancient history, languages and such that deceptively appeared to be the least magical classes of all.

Still, it wouldn't do making too many assumptions about the upcoming year before Phineas even attended his first class of the day, first day of the week. He quickened his pace through the old halls of the fortress, not wanting to be late. Phineas had rushed breakfast and barely managed to get his second-hand books and magical tools ready for the day.

As he entered his first class of the day, Phineas checked his schedule to remember what subject it was:

113.content:
A sour mixture of regret and fear shot through Phineas's spine as he suddenly remembered his first class of the semester: "Extraplanar Studies: Contact, Vergence, & Summoning". Extraplanar Studies was a special subject; though technically a continuation of other interdimensional classes, it was closed off to all but the most accomplished students due to its inherent danger. Many of its lessons involved direct contact with demons, spirits, and other ne'er-do-well ethereals hell-bent on messing with those foolish to contact them.

There we many stories of those who did not make it out of the class in one piece. One such tale was that of Alarian, one of the top students of his day. The cocky young man had made a sly quip at a demonic entity, prompting the creature to drag him across the veil to his own realm. By the time the attending teacher intervened and pulled him out, the handsome young man had been reduced to a fat, brainless goblin. Demon-magic being powerful as it was, it is said that he never returned to normal.

So why then was Phineas of all people going there? A few years before, one of his most accomplished cousins had managed to seduce and bind a succubus during the middle of a lesson; a feat never thought possible. He became the talk of the town and yet another addition to his family's massive legacy and for that reason Phineas's own parents had forced him into the class as a means to get his own glory, even at the expense of his own well-being.

As he stumbled awkwardly into the room, he scanned the tiny crowd of students for some familiar faces. He recognized them all, but only cared about a few; all of them girls, and all of them the object of his affections.

The first was Cassandra Betteridge, a member of the Betteridge noble family. Like many of her older sisters and relatives, Cassandra was rather chubby (most of her weight was in her waist) and growing bigger with each passing semester. This was due to her family's view on vain magic: only a truly insecure fool would bother to "perfect" their appearance. TRUE witches and wizards did not care about their looks.

The next was Lysandra Sosanna, a brown skinned girl from a foreign land. One of the brighter pupils of their year, she was well regarded for her naturally curvy figure: thin, yet hourglass. But most of all, she was regarded for his kindness. Lysandra was the kind of person who wouldn't even raise a hand to a fly, let alone one of her fellow students. Considering the occacsional cut-throat nature of the school, Phineas really adored that.

The final was Regina Celene, a short witch with a tomboyish body. Her personality was like the opposite of Lysandra's; whereas the former was polite and courteous, Regina was utterly cutthroat. She forgone study for cheating and bullying her way into success. She sought to bring others down; not raise herself up. The total opposite of what Phineas was attracted to, both in body and mind. Yet his dislike of her only fueled his desire to see her fattened, preferably against her will.

Fantasies of the three girls growing bigger and bigger occupied his mind as the class dragged on, before...

1132.content:
The class wasted no time in starting some practical summoning. Students were paired up, to his amazement Phineas found he had been partnered with Cassandra Betteridge. The chubby plump witch was a bit of a stunner, even though the Betteridge witches cared little for their looks. Or perhaps just to Phineas she was a stunner, with a cute dimpled face and long blonde curls snarled in a twisted weave. Cassandra would keep her quills, wand and other instruments in her hair for holding as she worked on a warding circle.

The circle was mainly for the students' protection, in each pair one was to work on setting up the wards while the other researched more on the entities and their home dimension. Demons, in this case, that Phineas should be reading about more intently given his share of the coursework. But he kept getting distracted watching Cassanda at work. She had sat on the floor with legs bent to one side, her pudgy knees just under the hem of her skirt. Her uniform was collecting chalk dust and soot, contrasting powders across across her plump form. Her chubby, pooching belly folded over itself as she bent over the circle.

"Was the arrangement in sixes or sevens," Cassandra asked Phineas absentmindedly.

"Uh, sixes," Phineas caught himself staring and focused back on the reference tome. "You'll want to intermingle barrier and restraint glyphs." At least Phineas had earned decent marks in past runic language classes, a help when crafting glyphs and sigils. And he was fair in early planar theory.

"Thank you." Yet another piece of chalk snapped in Cassandra's hand. It joined the growing pile of spent useless ends. "Can I get another--oh, thank you Fortescue." Phineas had immediately been ready in more chalk in hand. Cassandra sat up to take the offered chalk. The movement was just enough, Phineas was sure he could see a centimeter of skin from where her sweater had risen up...

There was a loud crack and an increased smell of brimstone. Next to where Cassandra and Phineas were working Lysandra Sosanna and Regina Celene had been paired together. Only something had gone wrong, as a pillar of hellfire ate through the ceiling from above their broken circle.

"Nice going Lysandra!" Regina jeered, more annoyed than properly terrified like the rest of the students backing away as something was primed to emerge from the beyond. Lysandra was frozen in fear, wide eyed.

It was just moments before whatever had gone wrong was about to get a whole lot worse, with the demonic entity fully materializing in the midst of the classroom. Phineas felt he had to do something...

11322.content:
The Citadel's Extraplanar Studies classroom grew hot and dark, the belching smoke of otherworldly fires pouring out as something took form in the pillar of brimstone. The classroom was a small pocket freed from the usual protections of ancient wards abound in the great fortress, able to pierce into realms beyond comprehension. While the rest of the school was safe the students of the classroom were not. Only the glowing white runes of Lysandra's broken protection circle keeping the demon from fully materializing.

The runes! Phineas had it, if he could just complete the glyphs in time the aberration would be abated. Against his normal instincts he dived toward the circle with a fistful of chalk, willing the crumbling utensil to hold together as he starting drawing.

"Hey!" In his haste, Phineas didn't realize he had tripped over Regina, knocking her further towards the intruding calamity. A horrid arm of red scarred flesh grabbed her from within the limited range of the broken circle. Black nails pierced her muscles, Regina's screams drowned out as sound was sucked into the incursion from another realm.

"I've got you!" Lsyandra reached out to grab hold of Regina, although this proved to be a mistake. The brash lithe girl's mouth was twisted in agony and her eyes glowed strangely, something flowing within her veins. This corruption was contagious, as Lsyandra's mouth also went slack as her eyes turned an unnatural color.

Buckling down, Phineas hurriedly scratched out the remaining words of the circle, hoping it would be enough to abate the demon's entry. He heard a cry of his name and by the time Phineas comprehended the warning it was too late.

"Fortescue! Those aren't..."

Catching the error, Cassandra tried to warn Phineas of what he had done. The completed runes glowed for a decidedly different reason as Phineas felt his throat close tight with trepidation. He hadn't completed binding runes but rather explosive ones...


Magical disasters tended to be spectacular, explosive affairs. Botching an already broken extraplanar circle with explosive runes certainly took the cake and threw it under the path of frenzied breeding dragons. The Citadel would have been destroyed numerous times over if its stones weren't used to the most violent demonstrations of magical backlash.

A fine layer of soot covered everything, the smoke of the wrecked room decidedly of this world rather than the next. Desks, books, personal belongings and more had been damaged badly in the blast. Witches and wizards tended to bounce back from most injuries, thankfully, whether from inner magic or artful use of magical medicine, so nobody was hurt beyond bumps and bruises.

Despite the derelict settings around him, Phineas had managed to land someplace soft. The traumatic encounter was ignored as he tested this odd softness. Plush, giving, yet jiggly. He kneaded it joyfully. If he didn't know any better he expected this was...

His hand shot up from Cassandra Betteridge's pampered plump middle, as he realized he had dreamily been groping her stomach! The awakening came with a harsh cough from the ash in the air, a mix of sounds from other students coughing as the professor began going about the room, responding to the emergency that had occurred.

Not a sight of the demon anywhere, although a crater was left where the demonstration had gone awry. Two bodies lay prone within.

Cassandra also coughed as she sat up. Phineas kept his mouth shut up tight, although the Betteridge girl made no motion to recognizing that he had been feeling up her belly. She was caked in soot and her clothes were shredded, thick midriff bare as she hurried to her feet, light shooting from her wand as she went to check on the two in the crater. Guiltily, Phineas followed after her.

Cassandra hefted Regina up with surprising strength. "Cold. But she's breathing."

Following suit, Phineas bent over Lysandra's prone form. She had fallen face forward in the blast, oddly, and was also victim to her clothes being decimated. Phineas was conflicted whether to look away or keep looking at Lsyandra Sosanna's shapely buttocks.

"Calm down, all right, calm down!" A voice of authority pierced through the confusion of the aftermath as the professor approached. Conjured blankets wrapped up every victim of the blast. "Fortescue, glad to see you're alive for the words we'll have later." Phineas felt his heart sink, already anticipating what kind of a reprimand he would be facing.

"I want you four checked out at the medical wing, no exceptions, clear a path please!" The unconscious pair were taken to safety, with Cassandra assisting the professor. That left most of the eyes turned towards Phineas, well aware that he had just made a dangerous situation all the worst as he sheepishly trotted behind.

Although his roving eye couldn't help but pick up on a peculiar detail. Was it his imagination or did one of the girls seem bigger?

113223.content:
In the aftermath of the Extraplanar Studies explosion, Phineas had gotten chewed out by several instructors at the Citadel. Word traveled fast, with each of his other professors hearing of the debacle. The first had noted he was late because of having to be checked at the medical wing, while another forbade him from any practical demonstrations lest more improper explosive runes happen.

It wasn't a good first impression for his penultimate year at the Citadel. Phineas shrunk through each class, what with the ire of the teachers and the spreading gossip. Worst, he hadn't seen any of the other girls from that fateful class as the day wore on. How were they doing? Phineas felt he needed to apologize for his mistakes during the incident, he was so focused on trying to think of ways to make amends he hadn't been up to his usual classroom pastime of ogling the other hefty females on campus.

Would Cassandra ever want to work with him again, that disheveled genius whose pampered middle sent his mind racing? Could he ever make it up to Lysandra, the hourglass foreigner too nice to be subjected to demonic intrusion?

Although it hadn't been intentional, Regina was quite the b-witch if there ever was one. That didn't bother Phineas all that much. All this time agonizing over his mistakes during his first class had left him oblivious to the late hour. Classes were over for the day and Phineas had to report to detention.

He sure hoped attending detention didn't become a habit. Normally, students facing attention had to report to one of the unused classrooms. Various members of the Citadel faculty oversaw detentions, no student ever knew who was administering their punishment until that instructor arrived. Sometimes you lucked out, with a teacher only demanding lines or quiet study, but others were a lot more intensive. Grueling menial labor, tedious chores, or more oblique challenges that tested mettle. Usually no magic was allowed in detention. If it was an instructor that did allow magic, those frequently in detention would have rather died than faced the oncoming punishment.

It was with gloomy anticipation that Phineas arrived at the quiet classroom five minutes before the indicated hour. It had been quite some time since he had last served a detention, so he had no clue what could possibly be in store for him. Surely this day was going to get a whole lot worse.

That apprehension soon vanished once Phineas saw who else was present in the otherwise empty classroom. This was a surprisingly small detention, to say nothing of the other occupant(s)...

Before Phineas has a chance to speak, their detention is underway.
He's about to speak but catches Chelsea making eyes at him.
More students file into detection; the other girls from the planar accident!
1132232.content:
Phineas stood stunned in the doorway to the detention classroom. He recognized the girl seated at the desk right away. Everybody at the Citadel knew who she was, from her auburn shoulder length hair to her most outstanding feature...

The front of the classroom faced the doorway, so Phineas could gawk without having to change position. The stunner was Chelsea Morgana, currently at work on her nails. Red ones she filed delicately dressed in her pink cardigan.

And sitting on her desk were the biggest pair of breasts Phineas had ever seen.

It was quite obvious just what drew so much attention Chelsea Morgana's direction. Puberty had left her quite overdeveloped, what with her impressive knockers that left most males at the Citadel speechless. On top of that (or maybe because of those) she was one of the most popular girls at school. Any second of the day found her talking through large cliques of friends, laughing at in jokes and wrapping people around her little finger. It was all the more shocking that the buxom beauty was sitting alone in detention, quiet as a church mouse, and she hadn't noticed Phineas had entered.

Phineas caught himself staring at her expansive chest for a bit too long. Chelsea's more crude nickname of 'Chesty' was an apt one. Phineas didn't have many classes with Chelsea during his years at the Citadel but the looker turned enough heads in the hallway so that everyone knew she was coming. He did remember her being one of the first of their grade to develop (just about the time Phineas realized he loved chunky females) and she had only grown bigger since then.

Her pink cardigan looked quite snug, the buttons of her undershirt looking a bit strained. Almost immediately Phineas had a private fantasy about the extremely top heavy Chelsea hitting all the more full upstairs, her clothes suddenly unable to constrain her meaty mammaries...

Chelsea looked his direction, her gorgeous perfect face and hazel-green eyes with just a hint of eyeliner. Phineas did his best to act like he had just entered, averting his gaze as he crossed to the second desk over from hers. He sat staring straight ahead, only looking Chelsea's direction with his peripheral vision.

The buxom student went back to her nails, bored, as they sat waiting on the instructor to oversee their shared detention. That was right, detention! Phineas couldn't believe that here he was with one of the universally hottest girls at the school, both of them sharing a detention together. For once the reason for Phineas's attraction towards Chelsea, her top-heavy figure, wouldn't be one of ridicule. There were people who would willingly go to detention for a chance to sit next to Chelsea Morgana.

After all, Phineas hadn't intended to louse things up so much during class that morning.

A bit of sweat formed on his brow as the silence stretched on, him and Chelsea waiting for detention to get underway. He should say something, shouldn't he? This was his only chance to talk to her before life moved on, him the loser nobody and Chelsea the voluptuous knockout. He'd already screwed up enough today so how could it get any worse than what he had already done?
1132232.title: 'Chesty' Morgana

choices: Phineas gets to know each of the girls more and starts bonding with them.
It seems not one, but a few of the hungry girls help themselves to leftovers.
One of the girls suggests an alternative to serving time in detention.
Regina and Lysandra show odd behavior, is this tied to demonic influence?
11322324.content:
It was an agonizing last few minutes before detention and it had yet to start! Phineas finally worked up the nerve to talk to the incredibly busty Chelsea since their overseer had yet to arrive. He had already loused up today enough, so even if he embarrassed himself further the sting would be mild.

"S-So," Phineas began, catching Chelsea's attention from two desks over. "I botched a ritual circle in class today. What got you stuck here?"

Chelsea blinked her hazel eyes. "Potions, regrettably. Melted my cauldron and most of the classroom floor."

Even at the darkest hour things were starting to look up! Chelsea was not as perfect as she appeared, even capable of the same types of screw ups as an average bloke like him! He even kept his eyes fixed to her face and not the wobble of her turning breasts! With any luck, her scrutinizing-yet-ethused look meant she might be taking a fancy with him?

"When you say 'botched a ritual circle' are you talking about that blow-up in the first period of Extraplanar Studies?"

The other shoe had dropped. Phineas coughed. "Yes, well, I made things a whole lot worse..."

He trailed off, stunned at who else appeared at the classroom door. Not the instructor to dole out their detention but Regina Celene! She noticed Phineas and returned his gaze with a murderously sharp stare. That was fair, Phineas decided, even if she hadn't nearly been possessed by a demon today. Although technically the issue had been her and Lysandra's fault before Phineas had accelerated the chaos.

And then Lysandra Sosanna was at the door, after Regina had found a desk far enough away from Phineas. This surprised Phineas, as he thought both she and Regina would have still been in recovery in the medical wing. She looked more favorably towards him, seeing a familiar face compared to the icy Regina that had been through the same event. She crossed over to set to Phineas's left at the end of the row.

"How are you, Lysandra?" Phineas asked, breathless.

"Feeling somewhat better, thanks." When she wasn't in a panic her voice was so melodious. And she had changed to more informal clothes, given her uniform had been destroyed. Phineas felt his heart flutter at the memory of her exposed if soot covered buttocks.

And Phineas was most surprised, turning his head back from talking with Lysandra that even Cassandra Betteridge was at the door. Trully, only Lysandra, Regina and Phineas had been at fault for the incident, right? The same thought process was going through the plump Betteridge's face as she regarded Phineas behind her tangled hair falling over her eyes. She initially greeted him with a cold expression, although not with the disgust Regina's had. Yet, as she regarded that all of them in detention had sat in the first row thus far, she was more open to amending fences about the situation as she sat between Phineas and Chelsea.

"Why are you here too?" Phineas asked, amazed.

"My thought as well," Cassandra sighed. "More by proxy than anything, I suppose. I was lectured for not helping well during the incident, along with moving Regina too soon that she actually had one of her ribs fracture."

Regina scowled.

"An easy restoration," Cassandra replied, but she stayed quiet as an ailing faculty member came in with a stoop, signaling the start of detention.

"The misshaps you children get into just because you're learning magic."

Phineas sighed.It had been some time since his last detention but he knew of this professor's outlook. He had lumped them all in the same category of 'dunce' without referring to what had happened. He looked towards the other girls, sitting at rapt attention, except for Chelsea Morgana turned his way with a look of inscrutable mirth. Phineas grinned stupidly then turned his head to his desk, glum. Was she having a laugh at his expense? Or was she somehow impressed by the degree of which Phineas had gotten himself and the others in detention, given the gossip that had circulated the Citadel?

"Well clearly you can't be trusted with magic," the professor continued, the same tireless speech he'd probably given over detentions for the past century. "So some good hard labor will teach you had to better approach the privilege of having magic. Follow me."

There was a collective groan. "The detention was elsewhere?" Chelsea said, ignored by the professor. "Why not have us meet there instead? I've wasted twenty minutes sitting here."

Luckily, few students were about the halls of the Citadel at this time as the parade of shame lead Phineas and the girls to the source of their detention. Phineas had estimated the destination given the professor's old school method of punishment. The arrived at the kitchens, an immense space to match the population of the equally large dining hall, freed from the hobs' evening labors.

"You are to wash all these pans without magic," the professor instructed as he confiscated wands, trinkets and any other paraphernalia or yantras to enact spellwork. "And you are not permitted to leave until the task is done."

A drudgerous detention yet doable. Phineas was used to many dishes when his large family had get togethers, as dishwashing spells were frequently forgotten. Yet the task was suitably arduous. Not only was the cookware used for that evening's dinner present but many plates had been returned too half-eaten. Phineas had been forbidden from making an appearance at dinner and it sounded like the girls might have as well.

Phineas caught the sound of a grumbling stomach echoing among his fellow students in detention. He looked about in anticipation, trying to determine which girl it had been. Cassandra? Lysandra? Maybe even Chelsea? Whoever had her stomach betray her had remarkable composure, as did everyone else who didn't want to show that they had heard the stomach grumble or been the one to cause it.

"Well," Cassandra rolled up her sleeves. "This pile of dishes isn't going to diminish itself. Girls? Fortescue?"

Phineas and Lysandra joined her, as did Chelsea and Regina more reluctantly. And with that the detention was underway.

113223242.content:
The five students, the four girls and Phineas, split up the duties to wash that evening's dishes. Cassandra began sorting through the dishes in the pre-wash, dragging Regina into the task, as Phineas and Lysandra did the full wash in the sink, with Chelsea talked into doing the drying. The popular, buxom witch had a bit of a lazy streak, growing bored of the task as she waited for dishes to come, then finding herself quickly overwhelmed once Lysandra and Phineas sent cleaned dishes her direction.

"We are going to be here forever!" Chelsea Morgana eventually complained, after several minutes where it looked like nary a dent had been put in the mountain of dirty dishware.

"I can't believe the stuff the other students just toss aside," Cassandra Betteridge said, finding a plate half covered with potatoes, pasta salad, and a bit of remaining lamb shank.

"Hmph," Regina Celene grunted, taking a stack of dishes over to the sink where Lysandra Sosanna was scrubbing the inside of a pot, with Phineas working on cleaning silverware.

As he was washing he heard Regina exclaim, "how can you be eating that stuff?"

Phineas snapped his head back across the kitchen. Cassandra, with the Betteridge plenitude of magic and wit being more important than appearances, was currently eating the remnants of the dinner plate she had found, much to Regina's disgust.

"It's perfectly fine food," Cassandra said, "that would be chucked in the bin regardless. Scraped off or eaten off, it still preps the plates for the rest of the cleaning process."

Phineas heard another telltale growl of an empty stomach, right next to him in fact. He turned back to look at Lysandra, with a brief glance as he noticed how hip to her wide hip they had ended up in the process of working at the sink.

"Actually, I could do with a break," Lysandra said, "they didn't get us anything to eat during our time in the hospital wing and I haven't had anything to eat since breakfast. Do you mind, Fortescue?"

"No, n-not at all," Phineas replied, watching Lysandra turn with a 'thanks' as she walked over to join Cassandra, an ever-present sashay to her hips.

"You too?" Regina said darkly.

Lysandra had ignored her. "Is that shepard's pie over there? It's one of my favorites."

Regina snarled. "Don't slack off too much, or we will be here all night." She dumped another load of plates into the sink, splashing Phineas with some of the suds.

"Wait, we can take breaks?" Chelsea said. She had a pile of wet dishes at her station, as the act of drying with a towel was apparently too taxing for her. Phineas got a glance as to why, as Chelsea's cardigan and blouse had absorbed as much of the water as her towel. Not enough to make her blouse translucent, her cardigan covered that anyways, but the gradual soaking around her tremendous breasts gave a comical sight, as Phineas bit his tongue.

Soon Chelsea had joined the other two with scavenging dinner through the leftovers. Regina still tried to stay on task, although behind her strict veneer she looked somewhat jealous. Another echo of stomach rumbling punctuated her return with more plates. Although Phineas didn't fancy her, and she was rather cutthroat in class, he did pity her situation at nearly being possessed be a demon earlier that day.

"Was Lysandra right, about the two of you having nothing to eat in the medical wing?" Phineas found himself asking.

"What of it?" Regina retorted with a sharp look.

"Well, you can't work on an empty stomach. Nobody will care if you have some of the leftovers or not."

Pragmatism eventually won out, as Regina gave in to join the rest of the girls at the kitchen table. Lysandra noticed that Phineas remained at the sink. "Aren't you going to find something to eat too, Fortescue? That's only fair if we're eating."

"I'm fine, actually, not really that hungry," Phineas said, making a show of continuing with the wash.

"Somebody should stay on task," Regina said curtly, although through bites of a hastily made sandwich of beef tips on an uneaten bun. "We can't slack off for too long."

The kitchen quieted to the sounds of eating and washing. Phineas continuously snuck glances the girls direction, finding unexpected fortune in seeing his thick-figured peers (minus the boyish Regina) soon set to scarfing down the remnants of the dinner they had missed. If only the sink didn't face the wall, Phineas could have positioned himself to stay on task and keep his voyeurism less obvious.

Seeing as the other stations were abandoned, Phineas switched to catching up on Chelsea's lackluster drying, where he could turn while wiping down plates and bowls. None of the girls paid him any attention at this point. Given the small portions of the salvageable leftovers, the four had already stacked up quite a few plates removed of food-stuff.

It was a tantalizing scene for Phineas, imaging their plump bodies plumping further. Even Regina might fill out, as she was a surprisingly fast eater and had caught up to what the other girls had managed to polish off.

The sink was ignored in favor of Phineas finding a better angle to view the impromptu meal, as he switched to the intake station with a show of putting dishes in to soak. Barely paying attention to his work at this point, Phineas was caught off guard by a wrecked pot falling out of his grip.

"Huh?" Phineas exclaimed, taking in the ruined piece. The stout pot looked to have caved inwards, with a third of it missing. Phineas realized it was a potion cauldron, remembering Chelsea's story about the destruction of hers in her Potions class getting her detention. There was still some residue of the inert dregs of the potion in the pan, a strange magenta color.

As Phineas moved it to the sink more of the remaining fouled brew dribbled out of the dissolved bottom of the pan. The young wizard reflexively avoided having it splash on his clothes. The action made him realize that a trail of the ruined potion zigzagged around the stone floor of the kitchen to the initial pile of dishes, where the girls had cleaned off one end for their dinner break.

"Um..." Phineas wasn't sure if he should say something. Chelsea's story had the potion melt through the cauldron and floor, and the ruined cauldron proved that. Although that effect appeared to have subsided. Still, wouldn't it be bad if he others got into contact with it?

Nobody would actually eat food tainted with unknown potion. Phineas made up his mind that there was little risk at this point. Noticing the hour, he refocused on cleaning dishes in the hopes that the girls would help finish the task.

12.content:
The Citadel Academy for Rites and Sorcery was a fortress hidden away from the rest of the world. So hidden, in fact, that the only way to and from the school was by a locomotive steam engine. The train almost had the amount of comforts the Citadel boasted, spread across the cars that transported the students to and from school each start and end of term.

It was a lengthy ride, on average about six hours to get to the Citadel. It was a time for students to catch up with friends, for newcomers to learn about the famed Citadel, for those that liked to study to cram before school began, and for the rowdiest of the academy to have their last hoo-rahs before they faced the discipline of the institution.

For Phineas Fortescue, the ride on the locomotive had become boring. There wasn't much to do during the wait until the Citadel loomed in the distance. The landscape passed by in a blur, with few scenic landmarks. Most students clustered up in the carriage cars with their friends, friends Phineas didn't tend to have. Few had the patience or interest of riding the train with him if they had a choice.

And then once the locomotive arrived at the Citadel, it would be business as usual for studying magic. Phineas remembered how fun learning magic had sounded when he first attended the Citadel. Now that it was his penultimate year, that spark had diminished as the studies proved to be challenging, draining and taxing to both body and mind. In some ways, Phineas was almost dreading the arrival.

Well, it was almost six hours until the train reached its destination. What would Phineas do until then?
12.title: Riding The Train

123.content:
Phineas had been sitting by his lonesome on the train for a half-hour when he remembered the letter. The letter that had been addressed to him from his father. The letter he'd thrown with everything else into his suitcase because he'd been too tired to deal with the words of a man who had barely acknowledged him his entire life. Now that he was more rested though, he decided he had better read it. One disregarded the words of a wizard like Nicephorus Fortescue at their own risk, even if the one happened to be one of Nicephorus's children.

It took some time for Phineas to trek over to the cargo car, and even longer to look through the accumulated luggage of an entire school's worth of students before he found his own suitcase. Thankfully, after that it was a simple affair to retrieve the letter from the suitcase, before Phineas trudged back to the passenger car and seat that he had abandoned. It was still empty, thankfully. Phineas would rather he have no audience for what came next.

The envelope the letter was in was made of a simple-looked yet elegant paper, one evidently resistant to being crumpled since it had survived the trip in Phineas's luggage without so much as a crease. One side of the envelope bore his name. The other had a wax seal with the crest of House Fortescue upon it. After looking at the envelope for what was likely too much time, Phineas took in a breath and muttered the incantation that would let the envelope know that the person intended to receive the message had gotten it. If he had gotten the spell wrong, the envelope would have burst into flame in Phineas's hands, destroying any message within. Instead, the wax seal faded away, and Phineas was able to open the envelope and retrieve what was within.

What was within was a letter. Phineas hadn't received too many of them, but he could still recognize his father's elegant script right away. At first, the message seemed formulaic enough. Words about doing well in school and upholding the honor of the Fortescue family seemed ordinary enough. It was right around the middle of the letter that Phineas read a sentence that would change his life forever.

... and so to ensure the continued prosperity of the Fortescue family, you have been brethothed to a scion of the Forsyth family...

It took a moment for Phineas to remind himself to breath. Betrothed? He was going to be married off? He hadn't even managed to ask a girl out on a date yet, and then this out of nowhere? Suddenly, his not enough breathing problem had been replaced with a too much breathing problem, and he had to take a moment to reorient himself before he started hyperventilating. He wasn't sure how long he spent trying to calm himself down, but finally Phineas was breathing not too fast and not too slow.

After he could start to think again, Phineas looked back at the sentence. He was to be married to one of the Forsyths. Looking at it from a purely rational perspective, Phineas could see the logic in it. The feud between the Fortescues and the Forsyths had been one of the longer-running rivalries in the magical world, and he knew that his father had been negotiating some kind of alliance with the head of the Forsyth family. In families with as much history as Phineas's had, a marriage between members of the two families was still considered to be a good way to seal an alliance.

Being a pawn in a political game did not seem like a fun idea to Phineas, and he imagined it would be even less so to the Forsyth girl who was now his fiancé. There were two he could think of, both in his year. He'd kept his distance from the Forsyth twins for the reasons he'd kept his distance from most everybody, but he supposed that would have to change if he wanted any semblance of happiness in a marriage that had been decided for him. Of course, that would depend upon which of the twins he was set to marry.

The older of the two sisters by an hour was Farah Forsyth, who comported herself with the grace and dignity one would expect of a noblewoman. She was one of the top students in their year and had a small but respectable circle of friends. Many knew her as "the Ice Queen of Vinixvue Tower," but it would appear that the gossip of lesser students didn't get to her. That or she had very impressive poker face.

Then there was Faye Forsyth, who had started her school career much like her sister had but soon had veered off into her own circle of friends and interests. It had been a minor scandal when she'd been moved into Wrocklehurst Cellar with the other "problem" students, but it didn't seem to slow her down. While she wasn't as academically talented as Farah, Faye made up for it by trying to befriend everyone around her. She'd even tried to get to know Phineas, though he'd shied away from her outstretched hand like he'd shied away from everyone else. Quite a few students whispered about her supposed promiscuity, though Phineas suspected that many of the rumors were fueled by jealousy.

Phineas shook his head. He was stalling. Better to read the rest of the letter, and get on with a life that was now inextricably linked to one of the Forsyth sisters.

124.content:
"Hey there, Finny! Over here!"

Phineas whirled around as he heard that nickname shouted at him. He'd been so lost in his own melancholic thoughts that it took him a moment to recognize the source of the voice. When he did, he went over to the seat where the voice had come from, dragging his luggage along with him. He smiled as he did so. The voice belonged to... a friend.

It was still a novel concept to him. He, Phineas Fortescue, knew people who wanted him around them. He'd been pretty much a loner through his first years of schooling. And yet, during the last year, a unique set of circumstances had led him to striking up a friendship with the two girls who were now sitting on the seat across from him.

The girl who'd called out to him was Ruby Summers. She was red-headed and brown-eyed with a short and stocky figure, and possessed a loud voice and strong determination. She needed to be determined, since she hailed from a family of low-income farmers. Ruby could only attend classes at the Citadel because of a scholarship she'd earned through much reading and hardship, and she wasn't about to let this chance at making a better life for herself slip away.

The other girl who was on the seat next to Ruby, meanwhile, had an entirely different background. Azul de la Mar was the third daughter of the eminent de la Mar family, whose ancestral home was a castle built on a private island in the middle of the Mediterranean Sea. Like all true-blooded members of the family, Azul possessed eyes and hair of the deepest blue as well as dusky skin and a curvy figure. Azul had never needed to truly try hard at anything; no one in her family expected much of her, since she was so far down the line of succession. It was a shame, since she had enormous magical potential. Even putting in a bare minimum of effort allowed Azul to easily succeed in all of her classes. Fortunately, her laid-back and easygoing personality made it easy enough to get along with her.

Over the last year, Phineas, Ruby, and Azul had all been in many of the same classes. Said classes involved a lot of group projects, and it soon became clear that no one wanted any of them in their groups. Phineas was ostracized because social anxiety, Ruby due to her lowborn background, and Azul because she didn't get involved in the cliquishness that defined the social hierarchy of the noble children. The three had to work together, because there was literally no-one else who would. At first, Ruby and Azul's differing natures had made work difficult, but Phineas had managed to provide the cement that allowed the three to work together effectively.

And they had been effective. Phineas had never had a more productive school year than the one he'd had last year, and he had his two partners... his two friends to thank for that. All of a sudden, a boring and dread-inducing train ride felt a lot more bearable. After giving Phineas a moment to settle in, the three began to catch up, talking about how their summers had gone as well as referencing several in-jokes that only the three of them got.

However, as the conversation went on, Phineas began to notice a certain tension the air. He wasn't that good at reading social situations in the first place, but even he couldn't help but notice when Ruby began to wax poetical about her mother's home-cooking, when Azul complained that she'd needed buy a new wardrobe just before school since none of her old pants fit, and when both began talking about what kind of delights might be had at the welcome feast. Phineas shifted uncomfortably as he heard all this talk. He had to clamp down on his imagination before it ran away with images of Ruby stuffing herself full of steak and potatoes and Azul's butt getting big enough to ruin another pair of pants. He'd only just managed to make his first real friends! He was not going to screw this up!

If only he knew.

During their first year of acquiantance with one Phineas Fortescue, both Ruby Summers and Azul de la Mar had come to know a lot about him. Both girls appreciated his sensitivity, thoughtfulness, and even found his awkwardness endearing. They had also both found out, in their own ways, about Mr. Fortescue's preference for larger women. So each had decided, on her own, of her own volition, to try getting bigger to win his heart. Furthermore, in the conversation they'd had before Ruby had called "Finny" over, each had learned that the other girl had come up with the same idea. And in the end, both Ruby and Azul decided that...
124.title: Ruby and Azul

1243.content:
In their earlier conversation before Phineas had arrived, Ruby had been the first one to bring up her crush on the boy. She'd hoped that Azul, who she now saw as one of her closest friends, would help her try to win Phineas's heart.

"It would seem that you already found the best way forward, I think," Azul had responded, with a teasing poke at Ruby's soft midsection.

Ruby swatted Azul's hand away with a blush on her face, though she was glad to receive confirmation about her theory. For once, she was glad that she'd inherited her mother's stout build. If she hadn't seen the way Phineas had stared at Margot Francois's thunder thighs in Intermediary Binding last year, she might not have believed he was into chubbier girls like her. Nonetheless, she couldn't let Azul's teasing go unanswered!

"Don't think I haven't noticed how your butt's gotten bigger!" Ruby retorted hotly, causing Azul's lazy smile to widen.

"Perhaps I have put on a few," Azul responded, though her tone was clearly unapologetic.

"Yeah!" Ruby shouted back. "So don't... don't..." Ruby's voice died away, as a dreadful feeling crept into the pit of her stomach. There was a brief silence between the two, before Ruby asked, "You... you like him too, don't you?"

The mirth disappeared from Azul's face, as she looked Ruby in the eyes. "I do," she said in a soft voice.

Tears began to appear in the corners of Ruby's eyes. It just wasn't fair! She'd seen how other girls at school who had appeared to be the closest of friends went to becoming bitter enemies as soon as love became involved. Was her crush on Phineas about to ruin everything?

Ruby then felt someone grab her hands, and looked up at Azul. "None of that," Azul said, her voice warm and sincere. "Just because we both like the same boy doesn't mean that we have to stop being friends. I know it can work."

"How?" Ruby gasped, desperately hoping to believe that this might all work out.

"These new pants I'm wearing? I got them as a birthday gift from my sister's girlfriend," Azul said.

Ruby's brain stopped for a moment. "Isn't she married to the Duke of Milan?"

"She is. Judging by the way he looks at them when he thinks no-one is looking at him, I think he knows and approves," Azul responded, her smile becoming a slight smirk again.

"So..." Ruby murmured, not quite sure what else to say.

"So, we do this together. We help each other and him. I don't think he'll mind, once we loosen our belts a few notches," Azul said.

Ruby paused a moment. "Once we can no longer wear belts."

Azul snorted. "That's the spirit!"

The two of them had then discussed their strategy for winning him over, which was tabled once Phineas had arrived. The first part of the plan, which involved making Phineas flustered by discussing their growing waistlines, seemed to be working out pretty well. Azul enjoyed being a gadfly, and it was all she could do to keep from bursting out into giggles at seeing how hard Phineas was working to keep his reactions to their discussion hidden. Even Ruby, who wasn't as fond of teasing as Azul was, found it rather funny.

Eventually, the train arrived at the Citadel, and after everyone had gotten everything settled (thankfully, Phineas, Ruby, and Azul had all been assigned to Kunok Quarters, like they had been last year), the Welcoming Festival began. Ruby, in a flash of inspiration, challenged Azul to an eating contest and had declared that Phineas would be the judge. Azul naturally accepted the challenge, and the two dragged a confused Phineas to one of the tables that had been laid out on a pavilion, and soon many plates laden with food were placed in front of them. A small crowd soon gathered as Phineas nervously told them to begin. Some of the gathered students soon left, though some of the onlookers began to place bets about which of the two girls would emerge victorious (Phineas, wisely, was not one of the gamblers).

The winner, eventually, was Ruby, although hers was a hard-won victory. Scattered around the table were many, many plates, and the formal robes they were both wearing were both stained (contests not being very conducive to well-mannered eating). As bets were being paid to those who'd won, Phineas helped both Ruby and Azul to their feet, and then accompanied them back to their room in Kunok Quarters. Both were feeling rather bloated and not up to any more festivities at the moment, and truth be told neither did Phineas.

As he lounged in the Kunok Common Room, listening to the shouts and music outside, a stray thought popped into Phineas's mind. Were Ruby and Azul... trying to gain weight?

He dismissed the idea as soon as he considered it. That was ridiculous. All that was just Ruby being her usual competitive self and Azul going with the flow, as it always had been, he decided.

The next day classes began, and as the three friends began their penultimate year of magical schooling, Ruby and Azul's plot to seduce Phineas began to get underway. Unfortunately, the pair's plan would soon hit a very significant snag.

12431.content:
It took Margot Francois a while to put herself together in the mornings, which was the way she liked it. She liked to use her morning routine to help sort through the various problems and challenges she faced, and come to a solution. After all, who was going to sort her problems out if not herself?

She'd just gotten out of the bath and was styling her golden blonde hair as her mind turned towards one such problem that had been bothering her for a while. Like all children of the nobility who attended the Citadel Preparatory Academy, one of Margot's goals was to interface with the other children of important magical families in search of a marriage alliance. It was a surprisingly feudal way of matchmaking, but both Margot's parents had met during their schooling at the Citadel, so she supposed it worked.

Margot's problem was that her pedigree just happened to be one of the best in the school. The Francois family could trace its lineage all the way back to Francis of Normandy, who had been Court Wizard to the Holy Roman Emperor Charlemagne. As such, many of the young men vying for Margot's hand were, quite frankly, not worth her time. Few students at the Academy were. There had been one she'd had her eye on, but just thinking about the memory brought a frown to Margot's face.

Antonio de Panettone had been in line to become the Duke of Milan when he'd begun his schooling at the Citadel, and had actually gotten the title when his father had unexpectedly died during his last year. Seeing the advantage of the match, Margot had spent much of her time at the Citadel trying to woo him, only to be beaten out by Cerulea de la Mar. Last she'd heard the two had gotten married right after graduation. Just the thought of having wasted all that time made Margot's blood boil.

Which brought her back to a display she'd seen last night, at the welcoming feast; the impromptu eating contest between Azul, Cerulea's little sister, and some peasant she hadn't bothered to learn the name of. An eating contest that had been judged by one Phineas Fortescue. The quiet young man could present an interesting opportunity.

The Fortescues were, after all, one of Europe's most illustrious magical families. No one could say that she'd be marrying down by marrying a Fortescue. She also knew that she'd have an easy time seducing him, if it came to it. Margot wasn't blind, after all. She always made sure to keep an eye on her surroundings, and had seen Phineas staring at the heavier girls in their year (herself included) when he thought no one would see him. Margot smirked as she ran a hand up her plush body. It would seem that her extra fluff was going to be nothing but an advantage for this latest scheme of hers.

But what made Margot truly decide to commit to her plan to seduce Phineas was that it was clear as day that Azul wanted him. The way that she'd deliberately plumped herself up over the summer and that gratuitous display at the welcoming ceremony left no doubt in Margot's mind. She couldn't directly get back at Cerulea, who had stolen the man she wanted, but nabbing the boy her little sister was interested in would be at least some kind of revenge, and Margot supposed she could be satisfied with that.

Finally, her preparations for the day were done. She was wearing a modest blouse with a skirt that was not quite short enough to be considered scandalous. Margot's green eyes twinkled as she flounced out of her room. She'd have Phineas eating out of her hand within a week.

* * * * *

Azul could tell that she and Ruby were in trouble right away. She'd just arrived at Advanced Animation with Phineas and Ruby (the three having coordinated their schedules so that they'd have the same classes), when Margot Francois entered the classroom. She walked right by where they'd been sitting, with a deliberate sway in her wide hips. Phineas had been awestruck, and only looked away after Ruby "accidentally" jostled him. Before sitting down, Margot looked directly at Azul and had shot her a smug smirk.

Azul frowned pensively. She was well aware of the animosity between Margot and her older sister. A big part of the reason she'd been forced to partner with Phineas and Ruby last year had been Margot's efforts to socially isolate her from the other noble children as an indirect way of lashing out at Cerulea. Not that Azul minded; she found that she liked the two people sitting near her much more than the many children of counts, dukes, and bankers that she'd interacted with for the majority of her school career. So Azul had been content to let Margot play her games, since they really had only made her life better once she'd gotten to know Phineas and Ruby better.

But now it looked like Margot was after Phineas, and that Azul couldn't allow. She looked back at her table mates. Phineas was staring down at his desk, muttering something to himself. Meanwhile, Ruby was shooting her a worried look; it looked like she'd reached the same conclusion that Azul had. Azul mouthed the word "Later," and Ruby nodded. There wasn't much they could do now with class starting. But something would have to be done, else Phineas might slip from their grasp forever before they had a chance to tell him how they felt.

The rest of that day proceeded much the same, with Margot never saying anything to the three, but always staying within eyesight. Always doing something that would keep Phineas's chubby chasing eyes on her, whether it be swaying her hips as she walked, surreptitiously pulling out a snack in the middle of class, or once or twice bending down to pick up a pen of hers that had "accidentally" fallen on the floor. It was a maddening experience for Azul, who really couldn't do much to stop the blonde's assault on Phineas's psyche.

Finally, though, classes were ended for the day, and there was some time until dinner. Phineas, Azul, and Ruby all headed off for different parts of the canvas, to try and figure out just what was going on after the day they'd had.
12431.title: Margot Francois

124311.content:
After Margot's behavior during their first day of classes it was clear to Azul that she and Ruby were not alone in vying for Phineas's affections. Although Margot's manner of teasing and knowing looks shot Azul's way made it clear that this was just as much an attack against the de le Mar family on account of her sister, Cerulea. Something Azul was not going to let slide.

It was with that determination that Azul made her way up the marble laden steps towards Vinixivue Tower. Each of the dormitories left its impact on the Citadel's surrounding architecture, and the higher one climbed Vinixivue Tower the more opulent the construction. Diamond and gem encrusted stained glass circled the tower, with golden banisters and silver-wrought lattice work that was polished to perfection, especially on the opening week of the term. Centuries old oak made up the big doors to the common room. Azul opened the doors and immediately looked around for her quarry.

The shining, palatial student quarters were quite lavish and large. The year's new students were getting settled by student authorities, several cliques were mingling about and getting reacquainted, old friends trading in-jokes. The blonde Margot Francois wasn't too hard to miss, with her thunder thighs spilling out of her skirt as she sat on a leather armchair next to two of her catty friends eating teacakes.

Margot didn't miss the dusky skinned, brilliantly blue haired Azul as she made her way closer. "Look who it is, Miss de le Mar," Margot giggled, echoed by nearby students. "Missing out on the posh life?"

It was another loaded barb underneath pleasantries. For the first several years of her schooling Azul had roomed in Vinixivue Tower before she had gotten tired of the snobbish games of one-upmanship that permeated the elites of the dorm. It was moving to simpler quarters, Kunok Quarters in fact, that Azul had eventually formed a genuine friendship with Ruby and Phineas.

"Could I have a word," Azul said sourly. "Privately."

"Nothing you wanted to share publicly?" Margot said, faux-taken aback to a new chorus of titters. "I suppose I can honor that request to a former roommate."

Yes, in their younger years Miss Francois and de le Mar had even roomed together, and that thin veneer between politeness and fierce rivalry had existed since then. Azul was happy to have been freed of it since changing her living arrangements but she could still go toe to toe with the most stuck up Vinixivue had to offer.

"Look," Azul began when she and Margot had retreated to a quiet corner of the tower next to the windows overlooking the lower parts of the Citadel, after drawing the chic curtains, "Phineas is my friend and neighbor I truly care about. He's not some piece of meat to sink your claws in over some petty feud."

"I haven't the foggiest what you're suggesting, Azul," Margot kept the same friendly smile, although her tone was anything but.

"Come off it," Azul said, "just because Cerulea was betrothed to Antonio doesn't mean you can take it out on us. I'm not my sister and you don't even know Phineas all that much."

"Oh, you're not your sister," Margot said, true intentions showing, "but you blue haired de le Mar's do let your feminine charms weave their way into the most eligible of relationships." Part of the candid rivalry with Margot and Azul had been the interactions of their lineage, as the exotic de le Mars had often been the upset in several marriage arrangements throughout the year. "Yet it should have been my hand with Antonio before your sister ruined it when he inherited his title. And turnabout is fair play if you're trying to get in with the Foretecues."

"I had no part in the arranged marriage and you know it, it was out of our control," Azul said. It was only a marriage for appearances anyways. Azul didn't want the truth of relationship with her sister Cerulea and Antonio de Panettone getting out. Azul had shared that tidbit to Ruby in confidence on the train, with Cerulea and Antonio incompatible in orientation with Cerulea having a girlfriend. The de le Mar women had far more open minded concepts of relationships than many of the social elite, hence Azul's agreement to share Phineas before Margot stomped her way into the picture.

"Deflect all you want," Margot said, "because I shall have my revenge with wooing Fortescue away from you, and if it secures my relation with one of Europe's most important families that's the cherry on top."

"You barely know him," Azul challenged.

Margot smugly put one hand to her outset hips, brushing her other hand over the edge of her skirt with her tremendous thighs. "Oh, I know what little Phineas fancies." Besides her stellar lineage, Margot was quite attractive if on the heavy side. Hers was a classic rubenesque figure with wide hips and filled thighs, perhaps the one flaw in the eyes of any other potential suitor but a boon to enchant the heart of the shyest Fortescue lad.

Margot stepped to the side with a pointed look to check Azul's profile. "And while that ass of yours looks a little more porky, I must outweigh you by what, fifteen? Twenty pounds? You've seen the way he lusts after the biggest." She squeezed her plump thigh for emphasis.

Azul fumed.

"And while Mr. Fortescue doesn't look like much now, he could do with some polishing up. Admit it, I'd be better for him in every way. Really, that display of yours and your silly other friend at the Welcoming Feast was a hopeless attention grab, whatshername is such a lower class lout."

"Ruby Summers," Azul corrected.

"Who?" Margot replied, the name not even worth her notice.

"I swear to you, Margot," Azul challenged, "mess with Phineas or my friend and you will come to regret it! I'll show you just how 'meddlesome' a de le Mar can be."

"I'd like to see you try," Margot retorted.

There was an electric stare between the two young witches before Azul turned to leave. "Just remembered I did warn you, Margot."

"See you at class, then," Margot finished. "Unless dinner tonight will have a repeat performance."

Azul knew she would have to change her strategy with Ruby with Margot entering the game as their opponent.
124311.title: Confrontation in the Tower

choices: The classic approach - both of them need to get fatter than Margot.
Turn the tables - what if they got Margot to quickly lose weight?
Out manipulate her - tank Margot's reputation and occupy her time else ways.
Thick n intimate - Margot can't do much damage if they never leave Phineas alone
1243111.content:
"Margot??" Ruby almost choked on her chocolate. Azul had brought along some fancy chocolates, something from home as a treat to start the new term at the Citadel, as she asked Ruby to meet to update her on the situation.

"That, big-headed, ego-centric," Ruby had several choice words in mind, although Azul shushed her. "--skank, then."

"She certainly intends to meddle," Azul fumed, popped several more chocolates in her mouth. In past year, Azul would have savored the chocolate assortment to let it last a few weeks, but in one sitting she and Ruby had nearly polished off the extra large box. As to their original intention, both of Phineas' friends had upped their snacking, although that motivation went into overdrive now that there was an outside competitor in the mix.

"Why does stupid, Miss Perfect High-and-Mighty-Toitier than thou," Ruby talked with her mouth full of chocolate, enraged to the point of spitting but wouldn't because of the delicious chocolate, "even see in Phineas? She's never even given him the time of day."

"I know," Azul said, having not told Ruby the full story of Morgot's twisted aims of vengeance. A fact that would complicate their own aims at sharing Phineas' affections. "The real problem is I think she's right on outweighing me, perhaps both of us. When's the last time you weighed yourself?"

Ruby swallowed. "Um, before I left home I was nearly 12 stone." Even though her goal had been to gain more weight to be more attractive in her love's eyes, Ruby wasn't used to the idea of scrutinizing her size just yet.

"Only that much?" Azul was surprised, taking in Ruby's appearance. With all of her weight concentrated in the middle, the freckled redhead's pudgy figure was dominated by her doughy belly. That plumpness had left Azul thinking Ruby outweighed her, until she took in account their difference in heights. "Because I'm not even twelve and a half stone."

Ruby's eye grew wide at that metric, as she reciprocated Azul's sizing up as she looked to her friend's taller, exotic form. Azul was a knock with her namesake blue hair and eyes with how they contrasted her darker skin. And while she had the bulbous backside, there wasn't that much fat on the upper parts of her body.

"So I'm the smallest in all of this?" Ruby asked, ashamed.

"There, there," Azul gave her friend a comforting squeeze on the shoulder. "You'll outpace me soon enough with that appetite of yours. What's more concerning is that places Margot close to 200 pounds if she's telling the truth."

Ruby felt her heart sinking, as she reached for more chocolate.

"She may be the biggest now," Azul said, "but we have the advantage of being friends with Phineas. We can keep her from trying to charm him and play to our strengths."

"Right," Ruby said, confidence returning.

"The sooner we can get rid of her influence, the better," Azul said. The two friends began planning their strategy in this all out game of love and war.
1243111.title: Preemptive Payback

choices: Soon, Ruby and Azul both declare their love and aims to Phineas.
Smothered by the girls, Phineas breaks away, snared by another weighty beauty.
The pair can't prepare for each eventuality; Margot seizes her chance to woo!
Sharing Phineas soon becomes lopsided, does Ruby or Azul come out ahead?
12431114.content:
"If we're both in this together," Ruby said after she and Azul had finished the chocolate, "then that'll be our source of strength, two against one." In some respects Ruby had spent the past couple of days coming to terms with the idea of sharing Phineas. It was fun to talk about the matters with Azul yet some part of Ruby had still pined for Phineas as a solo act of courtship. This had thrown her off her game, especially as Margot Francois stated her intent to interfere, leaving Ruby a bit weepy in the process of understanding what was going on.

Now that she knew Azul had the best of intentions to confession their joint love for Phineas, unlike Margot, it grounded Ruby back to her fierce Summers determination. Plenty had looked down on her origins before, working class compared to most of the blue bloods at the Citadel (if not blue-haired like Miss de le Mar) but that grit and gumption had got her this far into her schooling, about to ask Phineas out herself before the approach became sideways.

"It'll be like nursing new babes back at the farm," Ruby suggested. Her family earned most of their income domesticating various magical beasts. "Whenever there's a unicorn foal or a hod pup born, we're there alongside the mother. Doubly so if it's a rescue."

"So neither of us should leave Phineas alone?" Azul summarized.

"Yeah, preferably both of us should be with him as much as possible so Margot can't get to him. And if we need to switch one of us should be available as the other departs. That could free up time to continue our efforts."

"And for school, of course," Azul said, earning a titter between them. Their schemes still became the forefront of their thoughts as they continued discussion. "I might have a word with the professors about switching my classes around. That'll also let me see if I can sus out Margot's schedule."

"You wouldn't happen to have more chocolates, would you?" Ruby asked, feeling peculiarly famished. Her height didn't do much for her stature, although her robust appetite would soon be dramatic results to catching up to the metaphorical "heavyweights" in terms of Margot as a rival and Azul as a co-girlfriend.

"Sorry, but I'll order some more," Azul said, as she continued with their options. "We have the advantage of sharing a dorm so we can always convince him to come back for a study session. Or more. Maybe we can join in on a club Margot will avoid."

"Good ideas," Rub said, mind elsewhere. "My parents packed some cookies in a care package, I feel like a taste of home."


As a new addition to her morning regimen, Margot Francois added scrying after she had done up her blonde locks into bouncy ringlets. She had somewhat of a skill in divination, although most matters of the future at the Citadel were tricky to determine given the magical wards built into the foundation of the school, along with the sheer potential of its students. However, Margot could still determine something as simple as which way one Phineas Fortescue walked towards breakfast in the mornings.

"Perfect," Margot said as she mentally noted the results from her crystal ball, taking the moment to do up her stockings. The hem ending just above the knee, it left plenty of flesh for Phineas to feast his eyes on, given how her plump thighs filled out her skirt. An easy way to charm the shy youth. It would be as easy as 'bumping' into him on the way to breakfast.

The execution turned out to not be that simple. Margot considered it a straight shot down from Vinixivue Tower to where she planned to interact Fortescue coming from his dorm. Yet unlike her portents in the crystal ball he wasn't alone.

Azul de le Mar was walking beside him, cracking jokes in what appeared to be an impromptu pop quiz, as Phineas read out questions from one of his textbooks as they carried their school supplies. And Azul was very pointedly not looking at Margot, although she had crossed to the other side of Phineas as if to block him from view.

Margot frowned. It would require her fallback plan later that day.


"Morning Finny!" Ruby greeted as Azul and Phineas sat at the table.

"Hello," Phineas was a little bleary eyed, having been woken earlier than usual as Azul asked him to help her review material they had learned last year to best prepare for their new classes. "Have you...been at breakfast this whole time?"

There were two emptied plates and a bowl with traces of porridge at Ruby's place setting, as she merrily ate at some bacon. "That early? I guess so, we're often up at the crack of dawn when I help on the farm. Morning chores before getting fuel for the day."

Or in this case for Ruby, the morning chore had been the fuel for the day. She had just about beat out the rest of the Citadel for showing up to breakfast early, her large appetite given a renewed drive to make herself more attractive in the eyes of her metal crush with Azul. Azul smiled knowingly as she tucked into her own breakfast, as Phineas was more careless in keeping his gaze flitted between them for too long.


Not many studied the Law & Government of magical societies to this advanced a degree, so Margot knew that their class was a handful of students, herself and Fortescue included. Margot's machinations for influence weren't only from family reputation alone, as she had political ambitions alongside marrying well, creating her new fascination in luring Fortescue away from her rival.

The small chamber for this class had raised benches and longboards along each wall before the lectern, so as Fortescue entered Margot prepared to shift her weight over a few seats to find a 'new seat mate.'

"Excuse me, apologies for being late." There was de le Mar yet again! Huffing slightly, the bulbous reared blue-haired harlot obvious wasn't used to brisk jogs. She didn't even take this class!

"You don't even take this class," Phineas said after Azul sat down after a word with the professor, although he was pleasantly surprised to see her.

"I know, but I asked to transfer last minute as I've been thinking about what to do after graduation," Azul replied, winded, as she sat her own wide hips closer to Phineas' seat than she had at any of their previous classes. "You make it sound much more interesting, Finny."

He was the only thing that made this interesting. Truthfuly, Azul found the class to be an actual bore, a lot of the material stuff she had learned second hand from her family's own political interests. Azul excelled far more at her spell work than anyone in her family thought, although alliances and clan loyalties were seen as more important. This class was going to be horrendous. But besides more time with Phineas, it was well worth the look on Margot Francois' face when she entered.


"Care for a drink, Phineas?" Ruby asked as the trio of friends met that evening. She had talked Phineas into joining her and Azul out on one of the balconies off of the Kunok Quarters commons. Azul was basking along one of the benches, catching the last of the suns rays, as Ruby pried open the crate she had been carrying.

"Pixie Malt?" Phineas read on the bottle.

"It's a favorite back home," Ruby said, having snuck around some of the Citadel's larders. "Non-alcholoic, don't worry, but it is said to lift your spirits!"

"O-kayy..." Phineas took the bottle. The drink had a warm, fruity, fizzy taste that did make him feel a bit giddy. He took a seat perpendicular to Azul's bench, as Ruby handed her a drink.

"Here's to another great year!" Ruby toasted as she cracked open her bottle. "Look at us, think to when we were the young sprouts at the Citadel, and now we are much more mature."

An odd message but Phineas raised his bottle all the same before taking another swig. Things sure were different than when they were younger, when he hadn't gotten to know Ruby or Azul personally. But it was odd how much of the day they had spent together already...

He was distracted in noticing that while he and Azul had taken a sip, Ruby had raised her head back over the railing as she continued drinking, great gulps passing from her throat down past her chest to her stomach. And drinking, and drinking...

"AHH!" Ruby gasped, refreshed, after finishing off her Pixie Malt in one long draft. Phineas looked stunned as Azul laughed. "I could go for another, there's plenty more if anyone wants." She stooped to fish out another bottle.

Azul had been surprised how forward Ruby had been in this endeavor but it was looking to pay off. If they kept this up, they would secure Phineas' heart in no time. It was almost a shame this side of Kunok Quarters didn't face Vinixivue Tower, because this evening's exhibitions would send Margot a clear message.


There may not have been direct line of sight but Margot fumed over her crystal ball over her evening scrying, as she began to plot.
